Avec cet argent elle veut faire un stock de matière première (Lait - Sucre - Café)

loans.use: To stock basic ingredients for breakfast foods

loans.name: Thavy

texts.en:
Mrs. Thavy K., 36, and her husband, Mr. Ka Hin, 45, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh, were married in 1988 and have six children, three sons and three daughters. Five of them are in local school and the youngest one stays at home.

Thavy has been a fruit seller for twenty-eight years. She buys many kinds of fruits from her village and other nearby villages and resells them in Phnom Penh. Mr. Hin used to work at a printing house for thirteen years but now he has stopped to create his own business with a taxi. He just bought one van for driving as a taxi but lacks some money for another.

Thavy is requesting a loan of US$1000 to purchase fruits to resell and to buy one van for her husband to drive as a taxi.

loans.use: Thavy would like to purchase fruit to resell and to buy a van for her husband drive taxi.

loans.name: Victor

texts.fr:
Victor A. is 53 years old, is married and a father of 5 children who all attend school. Since his childhood, he has been living in Assahoun, a village located approximately 50 kilometers from Lome, the Togolese capital. This is his second credit, and with it, he would like to buy a mill. The mill will help him meet the needs of his business. The profits he gains will make it possible for Mr. Victor to help his family's needs.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

Victor A. est âgé de 53 ans, marié et père de 5 enfants tous à l’école. Il habite depuis son enfance à Assahoun, un village situé à environ 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Il souhaite par ce second crédit acquérir un moulin pour son exploitation. Ce qui lui permettra de répondre à un besoin du milieu. Les gains issus de son activité permettront à monsieur Victor de faire face aux besoins de sa famille.

loans.use: Acquire a mill

loans.name: Dinh  Thi

texts.vi:
In 2002, Mrs. Dinh Thi H. joined TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam). For the first loan, Mrs. H. borrowed 2,000,000 VND (equivalent to 125 USD) and used it to raise pigs. She soon realized that this investment brings good profit, so she continues to use her next loans to expand her business model. Her business is doing very good. Each year she sells about 2 tons of pork. Mrs. H. uses her income to save and buy some valuable furniture for the house, such as a motorbike, a refrigerator, etc. She is planning to invest in planting fruit trees. Since she already has a large garden, this project is feasible, and it promises to bring good profit. Mrs. H. has 3 children who have a job and a stable income, and one young kid who is still going to school. This time Mrs. H. would like to borrow 9,000,000 VND (equivalent to 550 USD) to continue to invest in raising animals and farming. Her family's average income is 3,000,000 VND per month (equivalent to 185 USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Năm 2002 chị Đinh Thị H. tham gia vào Quỹ. Vòng vốn đầu tiên gia đình chị xin vay 2.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn. Sau 1 vòng vốn thấy rằng việc đầu tư vào chăn nuôi sẽ đem lại hiệu quả cao, các vòng vốn tiếp theo chị đã mạnh dạn vay mức vốn cao hơn và mô hình chăn nuôi của gia đình chị đã mở rộng. Chăn nuôi thuân lợi hàng năm gia đình chị xuất ra thị trường khoảng 2 tấn lợn thịt. Thu nhập từ chăn nuôi gia đình chị đã tích lũy và mua sắm đựợc nhiều trang thiết bị có giá trị phục vụ cho sinh hoạt như xe máy, tủ lạnh ..... Tới đây ra đình chị đang có kế hoạch đầu tư vốn vào trồng cây ăn quả, với thuận lợi gia đình chị có diện tích vườn rất rộng nên đây cũng một dự án có tính khả thi và cho thu nhập cao. Hiện tại gia đình chị có 3 con đang đi làm và đều có thu nhập hàng tháng ổn định, 1 con còn nhỏ đang đi học. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 9.000.000đ tiếp tục đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và trồng trọt. Thu nhập bình quân. 3.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Raising and growing

loans.name: Roeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Roeun N., 65, and her husband, Mr. Pich Chhun, 65, live in a small village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1965 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. Four of their children are married and live outside the family home and one son works in a restaurant.

Mrs. Roeun has been raising pigs for five years. Now she is creating another business of selling sugarcane juice. Mr. Pich has been a motor taxi driver for four years. He carries people from his village to other villages. Roeun is requesting a loan of $500 to buy a sugarcane juice machine and piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase a sugarcane juice machine and piglets for raising.

loans.name: Yorm

texts.en:
Yorm Y., 37, is a poor entrepreneur living in the Kampong Cham with her husband and one young child. She grows rice to earn a living and is able to make one dollar each day.

Farming is hard as the weather conditions have been difficult this past year. It is hard for farmers to depend on precipitation and they have to own a water pump in case their fields go without rain water. Normally, people grow rice two times a year. Certain kinds of rice seeds grow during the dry season and it takes 3-4 months until harvest time. The other kinds of rice seeds grow in the rainy season and take about 6-7 months until harvest. Rice farmers prefer rice that grows in the rainy season because it has a better flavor.

Her husband, Hoeun Chet, 37, sells palm leaves. Everyday he collects the palm leaves for sale. Many products are made from palm leaves such as roofs, baskets and other things. Yorm Y. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to purchase a horse for her husband to transport palm leaves.

loans.use: To purchase a horse

loans.name: Chukwuma

texts.en: N. Chukwuma is 34-years-old, married and has four children. He sells provisions like toothpaste, noodles and bathing soap. He is requesting a loan to purchase more basic provisions to sell to his customers. He thanks all Kiva lenders and LAPO MICROFINANCE for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell to customers

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Résidant dans la localité de Fana (Sous prefecture de Yanfolila dans la 3e région administrative du Mali), les membres du groupe sabougnouma sont des femmes mariées vivant en général dans des foyers polygames avec en moyenne quatre (4) enfants. Elles se sont connues par des liens de mariage et vivent toutes à sélingué.

Elles s’approvisionnent à sélingué chaque sémaine et vendent sur place. Pour pouvoir mener des activités génératrices de revenus, elles ont décidé d’integrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Elles comptent utiliser ce premier prêt pour acheter  800  kilogrammes de fruits et  600  kilogrammes de céréales pour réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 26.000 FCFA par membre qui aidera à faire face aux charges familiales.
texts.en:
Residing in the Fana area (sub-prefecture of Yanfolila in the third administrative region of Mali), the members of the group Sabougnouma are married women generally in polygamous households who have on average four children. They know one another by ties of marriage and all live in Sélingué.

They get their supplies in Sélingué each week and make sales locally. To be able to operate and earn income, they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. They intend to use this initial loan to buy 800 kg of fruit and 600 kg of grains to realize an average monthly profit of 26,000 francs CFA per member that will help to address family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruit, tubers, and grains

loans.name: Yin

texts.en: Yin B., 34, raises pigs and sell piglets for breeding as well as pork. He is married and supports three children, all teenagers. His wife helps in this business. He sells his piglets to other breeders for $40 apiece and also pigs for slaughter. The business is doing well, and his customers come to his house to buy. He is asking for a loan to expand his business by purchasing more piglets, buying pig feed, and making improvements to the pigpen.

loans.use: To purchase piglets, buy pig feed, and make improvements to the pigpen

loans.name: Ivania Patricia

texts.es:
En la ciudad de León, específicamente en el mercado La Estación, la señora Ivania G. se dedica arduamente a su negocio de pulpería donde comercializa los productos tales como aceite, jabon, huevos, pollo, entre otros.

Es importante destacar que el negocio lo ha desarrollado satisfactoriamente gracias al apoyo de Ceprodel por lo que le ha brindado créditos para invertir en tal negocio. Hoy en día una vez mas atraviesa la necesidad de invertir y para ello hace uso del apoyo brindado por Ceprodel esperando que su crédito sea otorgado y de esta forma lograr salir adelante en el negocio.
texts.en:
In the city of León, in the La Estación market specifically, Ivania G. works with great dedication in her grocery stall. She sells products such as oil, soap, eggs, chicken and other items. It is important to emphasize that she has been able to grow her business thanks to the support of Ceprodel, which has offered her loans to invest in her business. She is currently seeking a loan once again for her business, and is making use of the support offered by Ceprodel so she can move forward with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Ny Tum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank, which consists of ten members, is located in Prey Khmer village in the Kampong Chhnang province. The loan which they obtain will be used for different purposes. Mrs. Sok Ny T. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She sells clothing in the local market. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more clothes to resell and earn more profits. Her husband, Mr. U. Kea, is a jeweler. Mrs. Sok Ny T. is 35 years old and the mother of three children who are all attending the local school.

Six members in this group have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to resell.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
A raíz de su viudez y a pesar de que contaba con el dinero de la pensión de su esposo, Nancy se vio en la necesidad de trabajar por cuenta propia. Ella siempre ha sido ama de casa. Desde que se caso se encargo del cuidado de sus cuatro hijos, quienes ahora son mayores y tienen su propia familia.

Una de sus hijas ha seguido sus pasos y así como su madre, ella también se dedica a la venta de ropa interior de bebé. Por estos días, Nancy se ocupa de cuidar al menor de sus nietos mientras, su hija se encarga del negocio. Esto solo hasta que el niño ingrese a estudiar en los próximos días, luego Nancy  retomara su trabajo.

Con su negocio no solo gana la sensación de sentirse útil o el dinero extra para los gastos de la casa, su negocio también le brinda la oportunidad de proyectarse en el futuro como una microempresaria. Más adelante, Nancy y su hija están pensando abrir una tienda-bazar en su misma casa.
texts.en:
Following the death of her husband, despite having money from his pension, Nancy found it necessary to work for herself. She had always been a housewife, in charge of caring for her four children, who are now grown and have their own families. One of her daughters followed in her footsteps, and, like her mother, sells baby clothes. These days, Nancy takes care of the youngest of her grandchildren while her daughter runs the business. She will continue doing this until he starts attending school, and then will return to her work. With her business, she not only feels useful and earns extra money to meet her needs, but it also gives her the opportunity to project herself as a microentrepreneur in the future. Later on, Nancy and her daughter would like to open a store-bazaar in their own home.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wholesale clothing

loans.name: Amani Group

texts.en:
Happy has owned a small shop in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for four years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more commodities in order to increase her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Happy is 21 years old and single. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Mastura, who also has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more commodities in order to increase her current stock

loans.name: Raquel

texts.es:
La señora Raquel S. tiene más de un años dedicándose a la venta de frutas y aguas frescas por las calles de Nuevo Laredo.
Este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de su familia ya que es madre soltera y tiene dos hijos bajo su responsabilidad y para los cuales quiere lo mejor y darles un buen estudio escalar.
Don Raquel está solicitando un préstamo para la comprar de mercancía ya que en está temporada de verano tiene mucha demanda y le están ofreciendo una mercancía a muy buen precio, ella quier aprovechar está oportunidad  y así su negocio tendrá mas variedad de producto y mas ingreso a su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Raquel S. has already more than a year selling fruits and juices int he streets of Nuevo Laredo. Her business is the one and only source of income to her family because she is a single mother and has two children. She wants to provide her children with the best and good education. Mrs. Raquel is requesting a loan to buy merchandise on high demand during summer season and she is getting a great deal on this merchandise's price, she wants to take advantage of this opportunity to increase the variety on the products she offers and increase her family's income.

Translated from Spanish by Nina Delgado, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To Buy merchandise

loans.name: Totorilla Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Totorilla, inicia su quinto ciclo con 24 socias.
	
Las socias realizan principalmente la agricultura D. verduras, crianza D. animales y entre otras actividades la venta D. ropa, comida y abarrotes en general.

Judith es conviviente, tiene 30 años y 1 hijo, pertenece a la junta directiva D. su Banco Comunal, Judith se dedica a la agricultura D. alfalfa y verduras, sus ventas los realiza en el mercado D. abastos D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho. Judith tiene proyectado comenzar con el negocio D. compra y venta D. animales.

Yolanda es conviviente, tiene 30 años y 2 hijos, Yolanda siembra verduras, productos que venD. ambulatoriamente en el mercado D. abastos D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 300 soles, 600 soles, 900 soles  haciendo un total D. 14,050 soles D. prestamos en el Banco Comunal. 

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra fertilizantes, remedios, para el pago D. los peones.

Los sueños D. las socias son construir su casa, brindar una buena educación a sus hijos y tener un carro para transportar sus productos,
texts.en:
The Totorilla Community Bank has 24 members and is beginning its fifth cycle of loans. For the most part the members work in agriculture, growing vegetables, raising animals, as well as such activities as selling clothes, food, and groceries. 30-year old Judith lives with her partner and has one son. She is a director of the Bank. She grows alfalfa and vegetables and sells them in the market in Ayacucho. Her plan is to one day start a business buying and selling animals. 30-year old Yolanda lives with her partner and has two children. She grows vegetables and sells them in the streets of the market in Ayacucho. The members of the Bank need various amounts of money, 300, 600, or 900 soles adding up to a total of 14,050 soles. The loans will be used to buy fertilizer, medicines, and to pay workmen. The members dream of building their own homes, providing their children with a good education, and having a vehicle to transport their products.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, medicines, and to pay workmen

loans.name: Aun

texts.en: Mrs. Aun K. is 38 years old and she now lives in Pnao village in the Takeo Province. She is both a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice and a pig breeder. Now she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer to make her crop more productive. Additionally, she needs the money to buy piglets and pig food for her pig breeding business. Her husband, Mr. Chhin Troen, is a rice miller who has been hired by the other farmers in the local district. Mrs. Aun K. has six children. Two of them are employed in a garment factory, three are attending the local school, and the youngest is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Marta Delmy

texts.es: Marta Delmy B. D. G.  D. 58 años D. edad, resiD. en Cojutepeque junto a sus tres hijos, uno D. los cuales trabaja y los otros dos se dedican a estudiar y no trabajan ya que aun son menores D. edad. Marta se dedica desD. hace ocho años a vender productos plásticos tales como platos y vasos desechables en el mercado municipal D. Cojutepeque. Ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual espera obtener el capital necesario para comprar productos plásticos al por mayor D. manera que pueda surtir mucho más su negocio, el cual es su principal fuente D. ingresos.
texts.en:
Marta Delmy B. D. G. is 58 years old and lives in Cojutepeque with her three children. Two of her children are minors and are currently in school, while the third works. For the past eight years, Marta has been selling plastic products like disposable plates and cups in Cojutepeque's Municipal Market. She is requesting a loan so that she can buy more assorted plastic products in bulk so that she can offer her customers a wider selection of items. This business is her primary source of income.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy plastic products in bulk

location.town: Cojutepeque en el departamento de Cuscatlán

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. trades in meat. She sells on a tabletop at the market square. She also supplies other retailers and food vendors in her community. Mary buys her goods from Kumasi. She has been in business for over ten years and wants a loan to buy meat in bulk.

Mary is 48 years old, married and has five children: two sons and three daughters who are all currently in senior high, junior high and primary schools. Her husband is a farmer. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Dwenase, a suburb of Sefwi-Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Mary wants to expand her business and improve upon her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy meat

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina is 51 years old. She is married and the mother of eight children. Currently three of her children are in school and the rest are working.

Augustina sells smoked fish at the community market where she lives and started her fish sales seven years ago. She buys her stock of fish from Yeji in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana.

Augustina prepares and serves her customers with very tasty and good quality fish and, because of that, many customers buy from her stand. She has a high customer base as a result of the moderate price and her good reception towards her customers.

Augustina buys her stock of fish from the fishmongers, sometimes when demand is high. She requests the loan to upgrade her stock of fish. She dreams of giving her children a quality education through the proceeds of her business and she would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy more smoked fish and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Sakina Muhammad Saeed Group

texts.en:
Sakina baji, the wife of M. S., has lived in Chichawatni, Pakistan for 18 years. Her parents didn’t send her to school due to financial problems, but her mother taught her the skill of sewing clothes, which she is now using to earn income. Her husband sells fertilizer to farmers and to the shops and earns income. Sakina baji is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer to advance her husband’s business. 

This loan group consists of two additional people: 

Rani baji wants a loan to buy fruit to sell. 
Bushra baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.
 
Sakina baji is seated in the middle of the bajis.

Note: "Baji," which means "older sister," is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sorn Yoem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people living in Sam Raong village in TaK. province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. S. Y. is the 61-year-old village bank president. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Ben Ban, is a village chief. He is also a farmer who owns a piece of land where he cultivates rice. In this plantation, he faces an obstacle because his field is infertile. Thus, Mrs. S. Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field to make the crop more productive. She has a child who is a farmer who helps the father work. (Mrs. Sambou H. did not come to take the loan but her husband did, so he is in the picture instead of her.)   

Thirteen members in this group loan have end-of-term loans and the other has a monthly payment loan. EoT borrowers are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to support the field

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en: Rachael sells firewood to her customers. She is 60 years old, married, and has 6 children. She hopes to expand her business. She is hoping for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more firewood to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Nhien's Group

texts.en:
Nhiên Thị Nguyễn (id: 010102120001) was born in 1957. She lives in Xom Vang, Co Loa, Dong Anh, Ha Noi. She has two sons, both of whom have a job. Her family has a store at home where she sells cakes, sweet (candies), Coca Cola, etc. Her husband helps her sell, too. Beside her store, she grows rice and raises fish, pigs and chickens. Her family has a monthly income of about 4,500,000 VND. She is part of a cluster group. She has taken part in SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) for five years. This time, she wants to borrow 6,758,000 VND to invest in her general store.

About the other borrowers in her group:

Thành Thị Nguyễn (id: 010102120002) was born in 1969. She has one child. She wants to borrow 4,578,000 VND to buy piglets to raise.

Yến Thị Nguyễn (id: 010102120015) was born in 1961. She has two children. She wants to borrow 2,398,000 VND to breed pigs and poultry.

Hà Thị T. Đặng (id: 010102120014) was born in 1969. She has three children. She wants to borrow 2,398,000 VND to raise chickens.

Hà Thị C. (id: 010102120004) was born in 1971. She has two children. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy rice to make rice cakes to sell.

Sở Thị Nguyễn (id: 010102120011) was born in 1960. She has three children. She makes tofu. She wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND to buy soybeans.

Yến Thị Nguyễn (id: 010102120005) was born in 1970. She has two children. She wants to borrow 5,450,000 VND to buy feed for her fish and pigs.

Liêm Thị Nguyễn (id: 010102120017) was born in 1972. She has three children. She is a tailor. She wants to borrow 2,398,000 VND to buy cloth.

loans.use: To invest in her general store

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es:
Maruja es socia del Banco Comunal Pueblo Libre que significa Nuestra Fuerza en quechua.
Maruja es casada, tiene 32 años y 7 hijos, Maruja viaja a las diferentes ferias de la region en donde vende ropa, utensilios de cocina, productos de pasamanería y de las ferias compra cereales que vende en el mercado.
Maruja necesita un préstamo de 900 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de platos y vasos.
Los sueños de Maruja son aumentar su mercadería y educar a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Maruja is a member of the Pueblo Libre, which means Our Strength in Quechaua, communal bank. Maruja is 32, married, and has seven children. Maruja travels to the different fairs in the region to sell clothes, kitchen utensils, and ornamental trimmings for sewing. At the fairs she buys grains to sell in the market. Maruja needs a loan for 900 PEN to buy plates and glasses. Maruja’s dreams are to increase her merchandise and educate her children.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy plates and glasses

loans.name: Francisco Javier

texts.es:
Francisco Javier N. O. es un señor de 34 años de edad quien vive con su hijo de ocho años en una comunidad llamada Canalete localizada en Upala en la provincia de Alajuela, es un lugar semimontañoso y sus actividades económicas se centran en la agricultura y mayormente en la ganadería. Es una comunidad con una gran oportunidad de desarrollo y establecimiento de microempresas, tanto de agroindustria como  comercio

Desde hace poco mas de diez años que don Francisco se dedica a la ebanistería , pero fue hace aproximadamente un año que puso su propio negocio. Él construye muebles de diferentes diseños y para diferentes usos. Dice que desde que inicio el proyecto los resultados han sido buenos ya que ha tenido una gran aceptación en su comunidad y los ingresos que ha generado lo han ayudado a sacar adelante a su familia.
 
En estos momentos lo que desea don Francisco es solicitar un préstamo  por ¢680,000 (seiscientos ochenta mil colones) para comprar una lijadora, una maquina canteadora y más madera entre otros materiales que necesita para la elaboración de los muebles. Con esto espera que su microempresa crezca y llegue a generar más ingresos para mejorar su condición de vida. 

Don Francisco es socio  de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Canalete, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su primer préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Francisco Javier N. O. is 34 years old and has been living in the community of Canalete for 8 years. Located in the province of Alajuela, the community lies in a semi-mountainous region where the main economic activities are agriculture and livestock breeding. It is a community that has great opportunity for development and establishment of micro-enterprises in both agribusiness and commercial trade.

For the past 10 years, Don Francisco has been dedicated to woodwork but only started his own business approximately one year ago. He builds furniture in different designs and for different uses. Since starting his business, he says the results have been good and his work is widely accepted in the community. The revenues he has generated have helped to support his family.

At the moment, Don Francisco is requesting a loan of 680,000 colones to buy a sander, an edging machine, wood, and other materials needed for making furniture. He hopes to continue growing as a micro-entrepreneur so that he can generate more income to improve his living conditions.

Don Francisco is a member of the Community Credit Enterprise of Canalete, one of 100 partner organizations that make up EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be his first loan and he hopes to continue growing personally and financially. He is an active participant of his local credit organization.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a sander, an edging machine, and materials for making furniture

loans.name: Batbaatar

texts.en: N. lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live in a rented ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in a ger district on the outskirts of the city. She has a son, 9, and twin daughters, 7, who all attend a local secondary school. N. operates a household-goods retail business at the Bumbugur market, one of the largest and most well-known markets in Ulaanbaatar. She sells plastic and glass goods and some electronic goods used in food preparation and home upkeep. Her working capital now exceeds 2,000,000 tugrug and with the business profits, she was able to purchase a car for her husband to start a taxi service in order to supplement the family’s income. She hopes that both her and her husband’s businesses will enable them to have their own house in the future so that they can be more comfortable and stop renting a ger. N. is requesting an 800,000 tugrug loan in order to import more household products from China. XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team lending team. To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here here.

loans.use: To import more household products from China

loans.name: Clarice

texts.es: La señora Clarice es una socia trabajadora y activa, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa región de Ucayali, tiene 39 años y es una madre, felizmente casada, con tres hijos, ella trabaja  junto a su esposo en la venta y recarga de extintores. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Carmen Cabrejos” desde hace 6 años, el primer préstamo que obtuvo fue de 300 soles y lo utilizó para comprar  gaseosas y venderlas en su casa, es una actividad que ya no realiza porque empezó a ver otro tipo de negocio que le sea mas rentable. En la actualidad ella requiere un préstamo de 800 soles que utilizará para comprar polvo químico y de esa manera recargar extintores. La meta de Clarice es tener una tienda de repuestos y lubricantes de motos y motokar.
texts.en:
Clarice, 39, has been a hard-working, active member of the "Carmen Cabrejos" communal bank for 6 years now. She lives in the city of Pucallpa, Ucayali region, is happily married, and the mother of three children. She and her husband work recharging fire extinguishers. With her initial, 300 sol, loan she bought soft-drinks to sell from home, a line of work she's no longer in because she discovered a different line of work that was more profitable. Currently, she needs an 800 sol loan to buy chemicals used to recharge fire extinguishers. Clarice's goal is to have a motorcycle and mototaxi parts and lubricants store.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy chemicals to recharge fire extinguishers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Obtain more land and increase production

loans.name: Imelda Patricia

texts.es:
Imelda S., joven propietaria de la tienda y miscelánea Mini Todo, ubicada en el barrio Los Girasoles de la Ciudad de Barranquilla, vive y trabaja  con su esposo, con quien comparte sus sueños personales como el de tener una microempresa bien surtida que permita incrementar constantemente su nivel de vida y prepararse para cuando tengan sus hijos.

Nacida en el tradicional y Guapachoso barrió Simon Bolívar de Barranquilla, donde su viuda madre la educó con sus hermanos, porque tenía un restaurante, del que fue desalojada y que continuó cerca al arroyo de Don Juan y al lado de un peligroso basurero. Esta fue la  razón por la cual, su madre la trasladó con sus hermanos donde su abuela materna para protegerlos y poder continuar con ese negocio, el que finalmente fracasó por los constantes ataques de los  ladrones y las inundaciones constantes del arroyo ya mencionado.

De esta  manera ingresó a la universidad sin el apoyo económico de su madre que lo había perdido todo, por eso habiendo vivido su experiencia de trabajo muy de cerca, se empleo en un restaurante y luego en una tienda, para sostener sus gastos y poder terminar su carrera, sin olvidar su gran sueño: “El de  tener un tienda bien surtida”.  Al terminar sus estudios, se casó, con Javier Pérez, empleado de una tienda, quien compartía su mismo sueño, por eso reunieron $2.000.000 para alquilar su primer negocio bien dotado de ranchos, víveres, y abarrotes, pero no alcanzaba a comprar su mercancía, es así como Arturo Martínez, asesor de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, la orienta y con su esposo participan el la capacitación empresarial y recibe su primer crédito por valor de $800.000, el cual es gradualmente aumentados al terminar de ser reembolsado, así recibió dos mas hasta llegar a $3.000.000. Con ellos ha logrado aumentar su capital de trabajo y adquirir vitrinas y estantería en general, ahora la tienda es propio  y tienen un gran desafío: “el de comprar una casa para no estar mudándose e invertir en adecuaciones en un espacio que aun no les pertenece, para ello  los esposos trabajan fuertemente y su amor es su máxima motivación.

En esta temporada  Imelda, planeo recibir un financiamiento por valor de $2.000.000  para comprar víveres, juguetes al por mayor y lograr buenos descuentos; el crédito será reembolsado en dos meses porque esta mercancía la venderá de contado. Esta pareja de esposos,  es  hoy un ejemplo de  unidad en el amor, persistencia y capacidad de trabajo.
texts.en:
Imelda S. is the young owner of the “Mini Todo” store, located in the Los Girasoles neighborhood of the city of Barranquilla. She lives and works with her husband, with whom she shares her dreams, such as having a well-stocked small business that will allow her to constantly improve her living conditions and prepare her for when they have children. She was born in the traditional and pretty Simón Bolivar neighborhood of Barranqilla, where her widowed mother raised her and her brothers. Her mother had a restaurant there, but she was removed from that location. She continued the business next to the Don Juan creek and next to a dangerous garbage dump. Her mother eventually took Imelda and her brothers to their maternal grandmother’s house to live, so that she could protect them and also continue with the business. The restaurant finally failed because of the constant attacks by thieves and the constant flooding from the previously mentioned creek. Because of these problems, Imelda enrolled in university without economic support from her mother, who had lost everything. Since she had had up-close work experience, she got a job in a restaurant and later in a store so that she could pay her expenses and finish her studies. She never forgot her dream, which was “To have a well-stocked store.” When she finished her studies, she married Javier Pérez, who worked in a store and shared the same dream. So, they scraped together 2,000,000 COP to rent their first business location, well stocked with snacks, staple foods, and grocery items. However, they didn’t have enough to buy some types of merchandise. Now Arturo Martínez, an advisor with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, advises Imelda and her husband. They participated in business training and received their first loan in the amount of 800,000 COP, which was gradually increased as the loans were repaid. That’s how they have received two more loans, reaching the amount of 3,000,000 COP. With the loans Imelda has managed to increase her working capital and buy vitrines and shelving. They now own the store and they have a big challenge: “To buy a house so we don’t have to keep moving,” and to invest in improvements in a space that isn’t theirs yet. In order to achieve this, the couple works hard and their love is their greatest motivation. During this season, Imelda planned to receive a loan in the amount of 2,000,000 COP to purchase staple foods and toys at wholesale price so that she can receive good discounts. The loan will be repaid in two months because this merchandise will be paid for up front by customers [as opposed to being paid for on credit]. This couple is an example of unity through love, persistence, and hard work.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase staple foods and toys at wholesale price.

loans.name: Santos María Luz

texts.es: Santos María Luz E. F. de 45 años de edad, reside en Cojutepeque en el departamento de Cuscatlán. Vive junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como albañil y con sus dos hijos menores de edad. Santos María posee una venta de tortillas en la cual las vende en el medio día y en la tarde. Hace más de 10 años que posee este negocio el cual le ha demostrado ser muy rentable, sobre todo porque le ha permitido solventar muchas deudas y pagos del hogar. Santos solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar maíz al mayoreo de manera que pueda obtenerlo a menor precio de lo normal, de esta manera ella podrá percibir mayores ganancias, las cuales beneficien sobre todo a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Santos María Luz E. F. is 45 years old and resides in Cojutepeque in the district of Cuscatlán. She lives with her husband, who works as a bricklayer, and with two young children. Santos María owns a tortilla shop, making tortillas and selling them at mid-day and in the afternoon. She has owned this business for 10 years; it has proven to be a quite profitable activity and has allowed her to pay off many loans and home expenses. Santos is seeking a loan in order to buy corn wholesale, allowing her to buy her corn at a lower than normal price. Thus, she will be able to earn a higher profit, which she will use to benefit her children.

Translated from Spanish by Julia Kastner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn

location.town: Cojutepeque en el departamento de Cuscatlán

loans.name: Norie

texts.en:
Norie is a tenant on a 2-hectare rice field. The income she gets from the farm is the only means to meet her family’s needs. She got married to her husband Felipe in 1983 and they now have nine children. Norie and her husband want to have their own farm to till so they can increase their earnings.

Norie is applying for a loan of 7,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies like fertilizers and seeds.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: The Women's Bank To Build The Future (2) Group

texts.en:
This group’s name translates as “The Women’s Bank to Build the Future (2)”. The group members are sisters who live in Sarapiqui, Heredia, a rural region close to the Caribbean coast of Costa Rica. The women members will use this loan for general investments in productive activities such as the purchase and sale of catalogue items. 

Alis is a 24-year-old mother of two. When she is not working on housework and child care, she sells various products in her community. Two days a week she travels door to door, offering potential clients the opportunity to peruse a catalogue filled with a variety of products from car parts to underwear. After collecting orders, she goes to a distributor meeting for her specific catalogue company and purchases the items. Upon delivery, she is paid for her services.

This loan will be used by Alis to finance the purchase of catalogue items for resale. She says her kitchen products are the most popular. She would like to expand her business and find more clients. She has been involved in this business for about a year.

M. is a 22-year-old mother. She is involved in the same activity as her sister, Alis, only with a different catalogue company. M. will use this loan for the purchase of products to sell in her community and to finance travel expenses. A difference between M.’s business and that of her sister is that M. must travel to San Jose, the capital of Costa Rica, in order to purchase her products, about a two-hour journey each way by bus.

loans.use: To finance the purchase of catalogue items for resale

loans.name: Safy

texts.fr: Madame Safy M. est une femme mariée de 29 ans. Elle habite a Ouest-Foire une cite de la banlieue qui se trouve non loin de la localité de Yoff. Elle est societaire de la caisse de l’U-IMCEC Yoff depuis juillet 2009. Elle n’a jamais bénéficié de prêt au sein de l’institution. Madame M. a 4 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 2 ans et demi et 14 ans.  Elle est secrétaire a Polyconsult  une entreprise de la place. Son objectif actuel est de démarrer une activité commerciale de vente de produits  cosmétiques. Elle est secrétaire depuis 5 ans. L’idée d’avoir une activité parallèle lui est venue du conseil de son mari. Elle sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs pour acheter les produits cosmétiques  et des tissus à placer. Son intention avec les profits qu’elle va réaliser est d’assister son mari et prendre en charge une partie des dépenses quotidiennes qui deviennent de plus en plus lourdes.
texts.en:
Madame Safy M. is a 29-year-old, married woman. She lives in Ouest-Foire, a city on the outskirts of Yoff. She has been a member of the U-IMCEC bank of Yoff since July of 2009. She has never received a loan from this organization. Mrs. M. has four children between the ages of two and fourteen. She is a secretary at Polyconsult, a local business. Her current goal is to enter the cosmetics trade. She has been a secretary for five years. The idea of having an alternative activity came at the advice of her husband. She is asking for a loan of 500,000 FRS to buy cosmetic products and fabrics. With the profits, she intends to help her husband and contribute to their daily expenses which are becoming more and more difficult.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Start-up fund

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To refurbish a poultry's corral

loans.name: Johanna

texts.es:
Yojanna N. varón tiene 34 años y vive con su esposo y sus tres hijos en las edades de 5 a 16 años, que estudian  en los niveles universitario, bachiller y transición, su negocio está localizado en la capita de Colombia, específicamente en el barrio minuto de Dios, el cual está rodeado de Centros comerciales, parques recreativos y ciclo rutas.     Johanna  solicita un crédito que invertirá en la  compra de  maquinarias de confección que adicionará a  su negocio llamado  Gavatex, constituido como una empresa unipersonal, donde presta el servicio de diseño, corte y confección de prendas de vestir desde hace 5 años. Este es su segundo crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo  y se siente contenta porque de tres máquinas que tiene en su negocio, pasa a 5 con este nuevo crédito.
Su sueño es continuar acompañando a sus hijos en su crecimiento personal y desarrollar su profesión y su misión como mujer; así como su gran desafío es también salirle al frente a la competencia que generan muchos productos chinos, que aunque no superan la calidad de los suyos,  la inquietan, por eso constantemente debe estar atenta a su mercado para fortalecer sus clientes rentables y no tener dificultades en la comercialización de sus productos; otro de sus  grandes desafíos es la  recuperación de su cartera en empresas grandes que constantemente deben ser controlada generando menos financiación para ellos.
texts.en:
Yojanna, 34, lives with her husband and three children, whose ages range from 5 to 16 years. The children are all students: university, high-school and pre-school. Her business in located in Colombia’s capital, specifically in the Minuto de Dios neighborhood, which is surrounded by shopping centers, recreational parks and bike lanes Johanna is asking for funds to buy sewing machines to add to her business, called Gavatex, which is classified as a single-owner business. She has designed and manufactured clothing for the last 5 years. This is her second loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo and she is happy because this loan will make it possible for her to grow from three sewing machines to five. Her dream is to continue to guide her children through their personal growth and to develop her profession and mission as a woman. A major challenge for her is to succeed despite the competition represented by the large influx of Chinese products. Despite their being of inferior quality to those she produces, she is uneasy nonetheless. For this reason, she must be constantly vigilant of the market in order to strengthen her profitable customers and not have any difficulty in marketing her products. Another great challenge is recuperating her large commercial customers which are constantly being controlled and having their budgets reduced.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sewing machines.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou C. is from the village of Tumpagon Cagayan de Oro City. She is 42 years old and married with seven school-aged children. To make a living, Marilou has a tailoring business sewing and selling curtains. She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Marilou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP — the first loan taken out by Marilou from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Early Fredy

texts.es:
Nuestro socio pertenece al banco comunal “COMUZONE”; Nuestro socio vive en la ciudad del Cusco, en el distrito de Huanchac departamento de Cusco.

Nuestro socio es el Sr. Early,  él tiene 29 años de edad, es soltero, nuestro socio es policía de profesión y alterna esta su principal actividad con el préstamo de servicios de taxi, Nuestro socio compró un vehículo y en sus ratos libres trabaja con su auto prestando el servicio de taxi, el socio aún no tiene hijos y solicita el préstamo para comprar repuestos para su auto.
 
Nuestro socio agradece y valora el apoyo brindado mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Early belongs to the “COMUZONE” Community Bank and lives in the city of Cusco, district of Huanchac, Peru. He is 29 years old and single. He works as a police officer and aside from this activity also drives a taxi. He purchased a vehicle and drives it in his free time offering his service. Early doesn't have any children and is requesting the loan to purchase parts for his taxi. He is grateful for the loan and values the support through these means and promises to fulfill his payments in the established period.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase parts for his taxi

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Né vers 1968 à Sikasso, Monsieur Mamadou B. est marié et réside avec son épouse et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Mamadou B., après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initié au domaine de l’aviculture depuis l’année 2006. 
Il dispose d’une une ferme non loin de la ville de Sikasso où il y a des centaines de tête d’oiseaux (poulets, pintades, oies, dindons, pigeons, etc.) 
Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses volailles qui sont de bonnes qualités et bien suivis par des vétérinaires qualifiés. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel qui lui permettra d’acheter, des médicaments et nourritures pour la base cour.
 Avec ce prêt il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born around 1968 in Sikasso, Mr. Mamadou B. is married and lives with his wife and their children, in a large traditional extended household, in Sanoubougou I, one of the boroughs on the outskirts of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mr. Mamadou B. unsuccessfully tried his hand at different activities, then began raising poultry since 2006. He owns a farm not far from Sikasso where he raises hundreds of fowl (chickens, guinea fowl, geese, turkeys, pigeons, etc. He is highly regarded by his customers for the quality of his poultry that are well controlled by qualified veterinarians. Wanting to satisfy an ever-increasing customer base, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, and is now requesting his first personal loan, which will enable him to buy medication and chicken feed. He hopes to reach monthly earnings of 150,000 FCFA which will be used essentially to increase his working capital, contribute to family expenses, and pay off his loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy medication and chicken feed

loans.name: Mon

texts.en: Mr. Mon T. is highly skilled at building stone and wooden houses. He receives a lot of orders from his clients to construct their houses. He has a partner in his wife, who appears in the picture above. She owns a medium farmland next to her house, where she cultivates rice crops. This couple has two children; both are students and live in the family home. Presently, Mon T. doesn’t have electricity system and he has been planning to connect it for a long time. Due to the fact that electricity connection requires a service fee, Mr. Mon T. has decided to seek a loan to be used to pay for connecting a new electricity line for the family's use.

loans.use: To pay for connecting a new electricity line.

loans.name: Regine

texts.en:
Regine is 57 years old and is married with five children; most of them are mature and one of them is a teacher. Even though she is middle-aged, Regine works with great effort at her business of selling various products out of her home. Regine has been a businesswoman for a long enough time; this is her second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. She has changed her business because these days she sells cosmetic products, water, juice, and so on.

Regine is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to continue improving her new business through purchasing more products which will help her to attract more customers. This will be one way of earning a lot of money. With extra money, Regine expects to have a big business, so she needs to save money in order to reach her goal.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is a 27-year-old married lady with two children who go to school. She operates a grocery store and a retail shop and has employed two people to help her run the business.

Cecilia has been an active member of the Jupiter SHG group of Faulu Kenya. Because she pays her weekly dues well, she has previously been guaranteed three loans by the group members.

Cecilia has requested another loan of 40,000 KES to buy construction materials and to add stock to her shop. She hopes to complete building her house and also provide a quality education to her children.

loans.use: To buy construction materials to complete her house and to add stock to her shop

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline L. is from the village of Palacapao, Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 50 years old, married, and has 11 school-aged children. To make a living, Evangeline owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2006, Evangeline joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Evangeline is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her seventh from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es:
Maribel de 39 años de edad vive en la colonia la Esperanza a 12 km de Nueva Guinea, tiene 3 hijos ltodos estudiando la primaria, su esposo se desempeña como acopiador de leche  para luego entregarla a la la empresa Lacteos el Zapote. Maribel labora como docente de primaria desde hace 20 años en la Escuela Deyling Olivas Betancourth en la colonia la Esperanza desempeñandose con gran dedicacion y empeño. 

Actualmente està  solicitando su 6to crèdito para construir una cocina con mejores condiciones ya que actualmente no cuenta con una. 

Su mayor sueño en la vida  es que su familia permanezca unida y poco a poco ir mejorando sus condicones familiares.
texts.en:
Maribel is 39 years old and lives in the district of la Esperanza, 12 km from New Guinea. She has 3 children, all of whom are in elementary school, and a husband who works collecting milk which he then gives to the company Lacteos el Zapote. Maribel has been working as a primary school teacher for 20 years at the Deyling Olivas Betancourth school in the district of la Esperanza. She works with great dedication and determination. At present she is requesting her sixth loan to build a better kitchen because at the moment she doesn't have one. Her greatest dream in life is that her family stays together and little by little continues improving their lives.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Fanning, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a kitchen

loans.name: Jean Damascene

texts.en:
Jean Damascene was born in 1981 and is married with one child who is 3 months of age.  Jean Damascene is a businessman but his wife is jobless; for that reason Jean Damascene works hard so that he provides all basic needs for his family. Jean Damascene is serious about his business; he starts his daily activities from 6 in the morning and works to 7 in the evening every day except on Sunday.

Jean Damascene is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business through purchasing additional products such as beans, rice and so on. These new products in his shop will help him to attract more customers. With extra money which Jean Damascene expects to earn; he will save for his future.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Idalia Francisca

texts.es: Idalia Francisca posee la venta de comida, por lo que tiene más de 31 años de realizar este pequeño negocio. Esta no es la primera vez que solicita financiamiento, pues tiene mucho tiempo de trabajar en Fundación. A pesar de sus problemas de salud, ha sabido sobrellevar su negocio sus clientes siempre llegan a buscar los deliciosos platillos que ofrece. Con el crédito comprara frijoles, queso, maduro, carnes, verduras y otros productos.
texts.en:
Idalia Francisca has a prepared food sales business. She’s had this small business for over 31 years. This isn’t her first loan request for she has collaborated with the Fundación for a long time. Despite health problems she has managed to maintain her business. Her customers always come by looking for the delicious dishes she offers. She will use the loan to buy beans, cheese, bananas, meats, vegetables and other products.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cheese, beans, bananas, meats, vegetables and other products.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph K. is 23 years old. He is married to an experienced trader with two children, ages 8 and 6 years. Joseph started a business in 2005, selling cigarettes, sweets and batteries. His business is located in Cotton Tree Market in Makeni. Joseph started this business to be able to generate enough profit to provide a livelihood for his family. Joseph works seven days a week and 11 hours daily. On the average, Joseph earns 2,494,000 SLL monthly from his business.

Joseph has a very good loan repayment history. He needs a loan of 4,000,000 SLL to help him buy cartons of cigarettes and batteries in large quantities. He intends to use the proceeds from this loan to educate his children and provide other support for them. He thanks you for supporting him.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of cigarettes and batteries for resale

loans.name: Las Estrellitas Group

texts.es:
El grupo se Llama las Estrellitas y se ubica en el Barrio Costa de Oro de Tecpatan, Estado de Chiapas México. Se integra de cinco señoras que viven en el mismo barrio, la razón del nombre es porque como son puras señoras se consideran unas estrellitas.

      La señora Irma Vázquez Vázquez es la representante del grupo y es la que se le entrevisto, vive en unión libre con el señor Fernando  López C., con el cual procreo dos hijas: Ana Gabriela de  nueve años en cuarto de primaria y la más pequeña es María Fernanda de cuatro años de edad.

      Ella se dedica a vender  lo que son productos agrícolas como son: pinol, polvillo, tascalate, como también refrescos, y solicito el préstamo para comprar ingredientes, como son: canela, maíz, cacao para prepararlo y no limitarse con su venta.
     Se inspiro en esta actividad para ganar su propio dinero  y apoyar a su esposo con los ingresos de la casa, inicio con esta actividad desde hace dos años y cuatro meses  donde le va muy bien, aun que tiene que salir a las comunidades cercanas a vender su mercancía para sacar mejores ganancias.

     Con la ganancia que obtiene compra más ingredientes  para seguir elaborando su actividad, y su clientela le siga comprando para  obtener mejores ingreso,  así poder ahorrar para comprar materiales para construir su casa más grande para que sus hijas estén más cómodas y felices.

    Lo que ella quiere es seguir trabajando el préstamo, para que con las ganancia que obtenga pueda ahorrar, así construir su casa que es lo que tanto desean tener, como también darle lo mejor a sus  hijas en su crecimiento.
    Las personas que integran el grupo son cinco y son las siguientes:

  Blanca Luz E. Bermúdez: invierte el préstamo en la compra de mercancía para surtir su tienda de abarrotes como son: azúcar, aceite, frijol, avena, entre otros.

   Irma Vázquez Vázquez: invierte el préstamo para comprar ingredientes como son. Canela, maíz, cacao, para elaborar: polvillo, tascalate y también vende refresco.

   Dora María López Benavente: invierte el préstamo para la compra de mercancía para su tienda de abarrotes, como son: aceite, atún, sardina, frijol entre otros.

   Florinda G. González: compra frutas de la temporada como son: mango, plátano y naranjas para venderlo en la misma región.

   Bertha C. Sánchez: invierte el préstamo para la compra de pollos por reja y venderlo aliñado.
texts.en:
This group is called “Las Estrellitas” (The Little Stars) and is located in the “Costa de Oro” neighborhood of Tecpatan, in the State of Chiapas, Mexico.  It’s made up of five young ladies who live in the same neighborhood.  They chose this name because the members of the group are all women and they consider themselves to be stars (like stars in the sky.)

Irma Vázquez was interviewed as the group’s representative.  She lives with her husband, Fernando López C., and they have two children; nine year old Ana Gabriela, who is in the fourth grade; and four year old María Fernanda.

She sells products produced on the farm, such as pinol (a corn meal), pinolillo (corn meal with cacao), and tascalate (a chocolate drink).  She also sells soft drinks.  She requested this loan to buy ingredients, such as cinnamon, dried corn, and cacao to prepare her products and not be limited in her sales.  

She was inspired to start this business two years and four months ago so that she could earn her own money and be able to help her husband with the household income.  Things have been going well for her, but she has to travel to the nearby communities to sell her wares in order to create better profits.

She uses her profits to buy more ingredients so that she can keep up her activities and so that her customers will continue to buy from her and she can increase her income.  In this way she can save up some money to buy building materials so that she can add onto her home so that her daughters can be more comfortable and happy.

She wants to continue working with this loan so that she can save more of her earnings and build her home, which is what she wants very much, as well as giving her daughters the best as they grow. 

There are five members of the group and they are:

Blanca Luz E. Bermúdez – She will use the money from this loan to invest in merchandise to stock her grocery store; items such as sugar, cooking oil, beans, and oatmeal among other things.

Irma Vázquez Vázquez – She will buy ingredients such as cinnamon, dried corn, and cacao to make polvillo and tascalate.  She also sells soft drinks.

Dora María López Benavente – She will buy merchandise for her grocery store; such as cooking oil, tuna, sardines, and beans among other things.

Florinda G. González – She buys seasonal fruits such as mango, bananas, and oranges to resell in the same region.

Bertha C. Sánchez – She buys and sells chickens

loans.use: Supplies and ingredients

loans.name: Otgonbaatar

texts.en:
Otgonbaatar D. is 22 years old young man, who lives with his father in Harhorin, the ancient capital city of Mongolian empire, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His father is retired and receives a pension for old age per month.

Otgonbaatar owns a carpentry business in his town. He used to live in the countryside and today he has his own 100 livestock. He began his wooden product making business in 2009, purchasing necessary tools and equipment after obtaining a business loan from XacBank. For the future, he plans to work as a carpenter in the Bat-Ulzii sub province.

Otgonbaatar is a very modest and hardworking man. He needs more funds in order to get married and live on his own, and is therefore requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more materials in order to increase his sales as well as to purchase a ger cover for his future home.

loans.use: To purchase a ger cover.

loans.name: Emerita

texts.en:
Emerita B. is from the village of Corrales, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 56 years old. Emerita is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Emerita owns & operates transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating service-based  services. Emerita is just starting this business.

In 2005, Emerita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emerita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Emerita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Emerita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Angel

texts.es:
El Sr. Angel es de la ciudad de Carapeguá, barrio San José, tiene 31 años de edad, es soltero.

      Desde muy joven empezó con el trabajo de curtiduría primeramente como ayudante de su padre, luego poco a poco fue juntando para su pequeño capital y así fue independizándose.

      Manifiesta que él mismo se encarga del proceso y luego de la venta de sus productos terminados como ser forros y vaquetas hacia las zonas de Itauguá y Asunción.

     Solicita el préstamo para la compra de cueros.
texts.en:
Angel is from the San José neighborhood of Carapeguá.  He is 31 years old and single.

When he was very young he began working in the tannery business.  He started out as his father's assistant then, little by little, he gathered together a small amount of capital and set up on his own.

He says that he himself is in charge of the processing and also the subsequent sale of his finished products such as coverings and leathers in the districts of Itauguá and Asunción.

He is requesting this loan to buy hides.

loans.use: To buy animal hides

loans.name: Pav

texts.en:
Pav S. is 39 years old and lives Battambang Province. Pav S. earns his living by teaching children who are learning in school. He has been working in this sector since 1999 and gets a formal salary every month.  He has a life partner in his wife, who is a seller.  She sells items like soft drinks, sweets for kids, and some cooking supplies. This couple is blessed with two kids, who are single and living under their care. 

Pav S.’s wife is doing well in her business because she has good communication with her customers and she sells her products at reasonable prices.   Pav S. wishes to support his wife’s business, and would like to request some funds from Kiva in order for his wife to purchase soft drinks, sweets, and other necessary items for selling. 

Pav S. was not available on the day of photo taking, so his wife is in the photo instead.

loans.use: To purchase soft drinks, sweets, and other items to sell

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia A. is from the village of Benhaan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 40 years old. Alicia is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Alicia owns & operates a venture in the manufacturing sector operating a furniture making business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making & selling general household furniture made from bamboo to local businesses and community members. Alicia has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010 Alicia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Alicia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional raw materials & working capital. Alicia is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Alicia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make bamboo furniture

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie is a farmer from Murang'a town in central Kenya where she has been farming for 16 years. She employs 2-4 casual laborers daily. Her main products are maize, milk, beans and eggs which she sells locally. She also runs a small business in the same location.

She has requested this loan of 50,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to improve her poultry project. The income from the sale of eggs will help improve her family's livelihood. She is currently rearing 30 layers but hopes to increase to over 2000 layers in future.

Winnie is 36 years old and married with five children who are between the ages of three and 16. Three of the children attend school.

loans.use: To improve her poultry project

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en:
Chhem S., 39, is married and resides with her five children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband sells palm products, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend 50 USD on food and 35 USD on the other necessary expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of  1000 USD to purchase a plot of farmland to improve the farming business. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland to improve their farming business

loans.name: Kayonza Twimuke Group

texts.en:
Anna is a member of Kayonza Twimuke group where each member guarantees for others to access credit. It should be noted that the group has eleven members although four of them did not take out a loan but were willing to guarantee for other members. 

Anna is a farmer and has been in business for the last four years. Her desires include educating her children and building a permanent house. Ann needs the loan to buy beans for resale.

loans.use: Buying beans for resale

loans.name: Iliana

texts.en:
Flowers were an important part of Iliana’s life long before she realized they could become her profession. While growing up in Guadalajara, Mexico, and after moving to the United States with her husband, Iliana frequently created flower arrangements for family events such as weddings, baptisms, and quinceañeras. 

When Iliana decided to open up her own florist shop, people told her that starting her own business was too difficult and she would fail. Now, six years later, she says that defying those predictions is one her proudest accomplishments. “Everyone told me I wouldn’t be able to do it– but look! Now they see that they were wrong. I was determined to succeed, and I did.” 

Owning a small business has not come without its challenges. Iliana and her husband founded the business with their own savings and, by sticking to a tight budget, successfully expanded from mobile flower sales in a parking lot to operating their own shop. “We are growing and earning more money, but it can be difficult each month to pay for our house, or business, and our normal expenses,” explains Iliana. “We didn’t even know that a loan was an option for a tiny business like ours. We couldn’t believe it was true at first!” 

A $500 microloan, her first from Opportunity Fund, helped Iliana to expand her shop’s inventory of flowers and gifts in time for Valentine’s Day, and consequently boost her sales revenue. This loan will also help her begin to establish a credit history and give her the option to seek larger business loans in the future.

loans.use: To increase inventory of flowers and gifts for Valentine's Day

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 46, she is married and lives in Lower Lamac, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. Mary has two children. She found ways to survive, and opened a “sari-sari” (general store) with a loan from Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) in October 2005. She was able to manage the business successfully; in fact, it covers her daily consumption needs and also her child's allowance.

 Now, she is applying for a loan of PHP 14,900 to buy additional goods for her sari-sari store. She will be happy if she sees her child finish school.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional goods for her sari-sari (variety) store

loans.name: Elnora

texts.en:
Elnora is a 42-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store and selling fish.  She lives in the island of Palawan. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and selling fish, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. 

Elnora is borrowing PHP 12,000 to purchase stock for her store and fish to sell. This will be her fourth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Elnora aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: To purchase stock for her general store and fish

loans.name: Pang

texts.en:
Pang Y. is a 70-year-old farmer and widowed mother who lives in Kompong Cham province. She is blessed with three married children. Pang Y. inherited farmland from her grandmother on which she grows different kinds of crops. 

Pang Y. presently faces a problem with her living conditions because her house's wall was broken and it is very hard for her and her family members to live in the house. As she doesn’t have enough cash for the necessary repairs, Pang Y. is applying for a Kiva loan to buy wooden poles to fix the wall. Pang Y., her daughter and her grandsons appear in the photo.

loans.use: to buy wooden poles to repair the wall of her house

loans.name: Joel Ntakaine

texts.en:
Joel is 29 years old, married to Christine Mausa and they have four children. He has practised farming in Naivasha town for the last nine years. He was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by his friend and this will be his third loan. He paid all his previous loans well and in good time. He plans to use this loan to buy seeds and fertilizer.
In the future, Joel hopes to become a leading farmer in the Naivasha area.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Sindi Tatiana

texts.es:
la Joven Sindi J. es una mujer trabajadora que se dedica a la venta de mariscos, actividad que realiza desde hace 4 años, sindi distribuye su producto a varios negocios todas las semanas, sus mariscos son de buena calidad y los vende a buen precio. Sindi todos los dias se levanta bien temprano para ir a comprar el pescado y los camarones.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de pescado y camaron, su meta es hacer crecer su negocio y obtener mayores ganancias, las que necesita para tener una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Sindi J. is a young and hardworking woman engaging in selling seafood, an activity she has been running for 4 years. Every week, Sindi distributes her products to various shops: her seafood are of good quality and she sells them at a good price. Every day Sindi gets up very early to go shopping for fish and shrimps.
She will invest the loan in the purchase of fish and shrimps. Her goal is to make her activity grow and to consequently increase of her income, money that she needs in order to reasch a better standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish, dried fish, fish fillet and shrimps.

loans.name: Rhaida

texts.en:
Rhaida is from the village of Barangay 4, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 33 years old. Rhaida is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling caps, sandals, towels, t-shirts, blouses, kitchen utensils and flashlights in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twelve years and earns approximately $230 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rhaida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Rhaida is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stocks of blouses, kitchen utensils and home products. This  will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:
